awd_titl_txt: TC: Small:  Distributed Privacy-Preserving Policy Reconciliation
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to enable collaboration between different parties it is necessary that the partners reach an agreement on the policy rules that will govern their interaction. While state-of-the-art mechanisms will allow the parties to reconcile their polices, today's policy reconciliation protocols have two main shortcomings. First, they violate privacy since at least one of the parties is required to discloses all its information during the reconciliation process. Second, they generally lack fairness, i.e., the parties' preferences are not recognized. This research is geared to develop novel techniques that enable both private and fair policy reconciliation.

The benefits of this research go far beyond the field of policy reconciliation itself. In fact, policy reconciliation is expected to play an increasingly important role in managing and securing infrastructures and procedures, ranging from day-to-day activities such as scheduling an appointment online, to enhancing interoperation in today's cell phone infrastructure, to the architecture of the Future Internet.

por.por_cntn:
While state-of-the-art policy reconciliation mechanisms allow parties to reconcile their policies, these traditional mechanisms have two main shortcomings. First, they typically require that at least one of the parties dicloses some of its information to other parties or some trusted entity in order to enable the reconciliation process. Second, these mechanisms by-and-large do not allow parties to specify preferences or do not properly recognize them as part of the reconciliation process.

It is in this context, that this project has made some major contributions and advanced technology considerably. Generally speaking, the project has resulted in the development of so-called privacy-preserving protocols which allow parties to keep their inputs (including their preferences) private, while enabling the reconciliation process such that no party learns anything but what it can derive from its own input and learning the result of the reconciliation process. In particular, the newly-developed protocols do not require any reliance on a so-called trusted third party but instead are carried out in a distributed fashion amongst the parties. The project has resulted in the development of a number of different protocols for two or more parties that have been proven to be secure against semi-honest (i.e., honest but curious) or malicious adversaries. At the core, the protocols employ secure multi-party computation techniques that make use of the homomophic properties of the underlying cryptosystem.    

As part of the project, various application areas for these protocols have been explored, including scheduling, auctions, and e-voting. The work has resulted in the development of proof-of-concept iphone and Android apps, as well as a library for privacy-preserving operations. For example, as part of the project we have developed a privacy-preserving scheduling app which allows a number of parties to find a common time for a joint meeting such that each party can specify its preferred meeting times, the preferences of all parties are properly recognized when determining the meeting time and yet all parties can keep their preferences and individual calendars private at all times. In comparison to traditional non-privacy-preserving scheduling apps our app not only provides all parties with more privacy but also facilitates an unbiased determining of a common meeting time. Specifically, a party cannot tailor its selection of possible meeting times based on what others have selected and neither can multiple parties collude in order to enforce a certain outcome (which is possible with traditional systems).

Generally speaking, the techniques, building blocks, and protocols developed as part of this project can be applied to any reconciliation application context where parties wish to keep their inputs private (including specified preferences) and yet seek assurance that the reconciliation is carried out correctly and their preferences are properly recognized in the process. Furthermore, many of the newly-developed techniques and building blocks are of interest beyond privacy-preserving reconciliation.
